{{Mesopotamian myth|expanded=5}}
The work known by its incipit, '''Angim''', “The Return of [[Ninurta]] to [[Nippur]],” is a rather obsequious 210-line mythological praise poem for the ancient [[Mesopotamia]]n warrior-god Ninurta, describing his return to Nippur from an expedition to the mountains (<small>KUR</small>), where he boasts of his triumphs against "rebel lands" (<small>KI.BAL</small>), boasting to [[Enlil]] in the [[Ekur]], before returning to the Ešumeša temple – to “manifest his authority and kingship.”
The ancient [[Sumerian language|Sumerian]] epic had been provided with an intralinear [[Akkadian language|Akkadian]] translation during the course of the second millennium.
==The Myth==
Three copies from Nippur provide a subscript labeling it a šìr-gíd-da, or “long song,” of Ninurta,<ref>{{ cite book | title = From an Antique Land: An Introduction to Ancient Near Eastern Literature | chapter = Sumerian Literature | author = Gonzalo Rubio | editor = Carl S. Ehrlich | publisher = Rowman & Littlefield | year = 2009 | page = 27 }}</ref> where the term ''long'' perhaps refers to the tuning of the musical instrument intended to accompany the song.<ref name=cooper>{{ cite book | title = The return of Ninurta to Nippur: An-gim dím-ma (AnOr 52) | author = Jerrold S. Cooper | publisher = Pontificium institutum biblicum | year = 1978 | pages = 2–3, 10–13, 53ff }}</ref> It is extant in unilingual Sumerian from Nippur during the Old Babylonian period, and thereafter in bilingual editions from the [[Kassites|Kassite]], middle [[Assyria]]n and neo-Assyrian and neo-Babylonian versions, where the later ones are closer textually to the old version than the Middle Babylonian.<ref>{{ cite book | title = The World's Oldest Literature: Studies in Sumerian Belles-Lettres | author = William W. Hallo | publisher = Brill | year = 2009 | pages = 60–61 }}</ref> Along with its companion composition, [[Lugal-e]], it is the only Sumerian composition other than incantations and proverbs to have survived in the canon from the Old Babylonian period into the first Millennium.<ref name=cooper/> The title comes from the opening line: an-[gim] dím-ma, <sup>d</sup>en-líl-gim dím-ma, “created like An, created like Enlil.”
The narrative relates that he mounts the monsters, “slain heroes,” he has defeated as trophies on his [<sup>giš</sup>gigir z]a-gìn-na, “shining chariot.” Echoing the number of [[Tiamat|Tiāmat]]’s eleven monstrous offspring, (from the [[Enûma Eliš]], whom [[Marduk]] had vanquished), Ninurta’s conquests included
* wild bulls he hung on the axle, * captured cows on the cross-piece of the yoke, * a [[six-headed Wild Ram]] (šeg.<small>SAG-ÀŠ</small>) on the dustguard, * [[Bašmu]] (Sumerian: Usum) on the seat, * [[Magilum boat|Magilum]], or "ship-locust," on the frame, * the bison [[Kusarikku]] (Sumerian: gud.alim) on the beam, * the mermaid [[Mermaid (Ninurta)|Kulianna]] on the footboard, * “white substance” (''gaṣṣa'', gypsum<ref>''gaṣṣa'' CAD g, p. 54.</ref>), on the forward part of the yoke, * [[strong copper]] (''urudû''<ref>''urudû'' CAD u pp. 269–270.</ref> níg kal-ga) on the inside pole pin, * the [[Zu (mythology)|Anzu]]-bird on the front guard and * the [[seven-headed serpent]] (Sumerian: muš sag-imin) possibly [[Mušmaḫḫū]] on another illegible part.<ref name=cooper/>
He then journeys with his attendants, Udanna, the all-seeing god, Lugalanbadra, the bearded lord, and Lugalkudub, with full battle regalia in a terrifying procession to Nippur. [[Nusku]] warns him that he is frightening the gods, the Ananna, and, if he can tone it down a little, Enlil will reward him. In the [[Ekur]], he displays his trophies and booty to the general astonishment of the gods – including his brother, the moon god [[Sin (mythology)|Sin]], father, Enlil, and mother [[Ninlil]]. Ninurta then extols his virtues in a long hymn of self-praise in an effort to solicit the establishment of his own cult. On his departure from the Ekur, he is petitioned by the god [[Ninkarnunna]] to extend his blessings to the king, perhaps the underlying purpose of the whole poem. The work ends with: <sup>d</sup>Ninurta dumu mah é-kur-ra, “Ninurta, the magnificent scion of Ekur.”<ref>{{ cite book | title = Greek Myths and Mesopotamia | author = Charles Penglase | publisher = Taylor & Francis | year = 1994 | pages = 55–57 }}</ref>
The ancient use of the text is uncertain. It may have been recited during some kind of cultic activity, such as the annual transport of the Ninurta idol between the temples, Ešumeša and Ekur.<ref name=cooper/>
==External links==
Ninurta's return to Nibru: a šir-gida to Ninurta at [http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk/cgi-bin/etcsl.cgi?text=t.1.6.1# ETCSL]

{{good article}} {{EngvarB|date=May 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox temple | name = Badrinath Temple | image = Badrinath temple.jpg | alt = image of the temple with steps leading to the entrance | caption = Entrance of the Badrinath temple | map_type = India Uttarakhand | map_caption = Location in Uttarakhand | coordinates = {{coord|30.744695|79.491175|type:landmark_region:IN|display=inline,title}} | other_names = | proper_name = Badrinath | country = [[India]] | state = [[Uttarakhand]] | district = [[Chamoli district]] | location = [[Badrinath]] | elevation_m = | deity = Badrinath ([[Vishnu]]) | primary_deity_Godess = | utsava_deity_God = | utsava_deity_Godess= | Direction_posture = | Pushakarani = | Vimanam = | Poets = | Prathyaksham = | festivals= | architecture = | temple_quantity = | monument_quantity= | inscriptions = | year_completed = 7th century C.E. | creator = [[Adi Shankara]] | website = }}
'''Badrinath''' or '''Badrinarayan Temple''' is a [[Hindu temple]] dedicated to [[Vishnu]] which is situated in the town of [[Badrinath]] in [[Uttarakhand]], India. The temple and town form one of the four [[Char Dham]] and [[Chota Char Dham]] [[Hindu pilgrimage|pilgrimage sites]]. The temple is also one of the 108 [[Divya Desams]] dedicated to Vishnu, who is worshipped as Badrinath{{mdash}}holy shrines for [[Vaishnavite]]s. It is open for six months every year (between the end of April and the beginning of November), because of extreme weather conditions in the [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] region. The temple is located in [[Garhwal Himalaya|Garhwal hill]] tracks in [[Chamoli district]] along the banks of [[Alaknanda]] River at an elevation of {{convert|3133|m|ft|abbr=on}} above the mean sea level. It is one of the most visited pilgrimage centers of India, having recorded 1,060,000 visits.
The image of the presiding deity worshipped in the temple is a {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall, the black stone statue of Vishnu in the form of Badrinarayan. The statue is considered by many Hindus to be one of eight ''swayam vyakta kshetras'', or self-manifested statues of Vishnu.<ref name=dhaams>{{harvnb|Sen Gupta|2002|p=32}}</ref>
Mata Murti Ka Mela, which commemorates the descent of river [[Ganges]] on mother earth, is the most prominent festival celebrated in the Badrinath Temple. Although Badrinath is located in North India, the head priest, or Rawal, is traditionally a [[Nambudiri|Nambudiri Brahmin]] chosen from the South Indian state of [[Kerala]]. The temple was included in the Uttar Pradesh state government Act No. 30/1948 as Act no. 16,1939, which later came to be known as Shri Badarinath and Shri Kedarnath Mandir Act. The committee nominated by the state government administers both the temples and has seventeen members on its board.
The temple is mentioned in ancient religious texts like ''[[Vishnu Purana]]'' and ''[[Skanda Purana]]''. It is glorified in the ''[[Divya Prabandha]]'', an early medieval [[Tamil literature|Tamil]] canon of the [[Alvars|Azhwar]] saints from the 6th–9th centuries AD.
==Location, architecture, and shrines== [[File:Badrinath-taptkund.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Tapt Kund hot springs next to Badrinath Temple, enclosed inside bath house|alt=a rectangular tank with a house on the bank and with people taking bath in the hot springs]] The temple is located in [[Garhwal Himalaya|Garhwal]] hill tracks along the banks of the [[Alaknanda River]]{{sfn| Baynes|1878}} in [[Chamoli district]] in [[Uttarakhand]], a state in North India. The hill tracks are located {{convert|3133|m|ft|abbr=on}} above the mean sea level.<ref name="about">{{cite web|title=About the temple|url=http://www.badarikedar.org/badrinath.aspx|publisher=Shri Badrinath - Shri Kedarnath Temples Committee|year=2006|accessdate=1 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214005611/http://badarikedar.org/badrinath.aspx|archive-date=14 December 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=India through the ages|last=Gopal|first=Madan|year= 1990| page= 174|editor=K.S. Gautam|publisher=Publication Division, Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, Government of India}}</ref> The Nar Parbat mountain is located opposite to the temple, while the Narayana Parbat is located behind the Neelakanta peak.<ref name="Nair67">{{harvnb|Nair|2007|pp=67–68}}</ref>
The temple has three structures: the [[garbha grha|Garbhagriha]] (sanctum), the [[Darśana|Darshan]] Mandap (worship hall), and Sabha Mandap (convention hall).<ref name="about"/><ref name="Nair67"/><ref name="Tyagi"/> The conical-shaped roof of the sanctum, the ''garbhagriha'', is approximately {{convert|15|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall with a small cupola on top, covered with a gold gilt roof.<ref name="Nair67"/><ref name=call>{{harvnb|Nautiyal|1962|p= 110}}</ref> The facade is built of stone and has arched windows. A broad stairway leads up to the main entrance, a tall, arched gateway. Just inside is a [[mandap]], a large, pillared hall that leads to the sanctum, or main shrine area. The walls and pillars of the hall are covered with intricate carvings.<ref name=dhaams/>
The main shrine houses the {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=on}} [[Shaligram]] (black stone) idol of Lord Badrinarayana, which is housed in a gold canopy under a Badri Tree. The idol of Lord Badrinarayana shows Him holding a ''[[Shankha]]'' (conch) and a ''[[Sudarshan Chakra|Chakra]]'' (wheel) in two of His arms in a lifted posture and the other two arms resting on His lap in a ''[[Lotus position|Yogamudra]]'' (''Padmasana'') posture.<ref name="about"/><ref name="Tyagi"/> The sanctum also houses images of the god of wealth{{mdash}}[[Kubera]], sage [[Narada]], [[Uddhava]], [[Nara-Narayana|Nar and Narayan]]. There are fifteen more images that are also worshipped around the temple. These include that of [[Lakshmi]] (the consort of Vishnu), [[Garuda]] (the [[vahana]] of Narayan), and [[Navadurga]], the manifestation of [[Durga]] in nine different forms. The temple also has shrines of Lakshmi Narasimhar and for saints [[Adi Shankara]] ({{sc|ad}} 788-820), [[Nara-Narayana|Nar and Narayan]],Ghantakarna, [[Vedanta Desika]] and [[Ramanujacharya]]. All the idols of the temple are made of black stone.<ref name=dhaams/><ref name="about"/><ref name="Nair67"/>
The Tapt Kund, a group of hot sulfur springs just below the temple, are considered to be medicinal; many pilgrims consider it a requirement to bathe in the springs before visiting the temple. The springs have a year-round temperature of {{convert|55|°C|°F|abbr=on}}, while outside temperature is typically below {{convert|17|°C|°F|abbr=on}} all year round.<ref name="about"/> The two water ponds in the temple are called Narad Kund and Surya Kund.<ref name=Bhalla190/>
==History== {{Chota Char Dham}} There is no historical record about the temple, but there is a mention of the presiding deity Badrinath in [[Vedic scriptures]] ({{circa|lk=no|1750}}–500 {{sc|bc}}).<ref name="Nair67"/> According to some accounts, the temple was a Buddhist shrine till the 8th century and [[Adi Shankara]] converted it to a Hindu temple.<ref name="Tyagi">{{harvnb|Tyagi|1991|p=70}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Sadasivan|2000|p=211}}</ref> The architecture of the temple resembling that of a [[Buddhist]] [[vihara]] (temple) and the brightly painted facade which is atypical of Buddhist temples leads to the argument.<ref name=dhaams/> Other accounts relate that it was originally established as a pilgrimage site by Adi Shankara in the ninth century. It is believed that Shankara resided in the place for six years from {{sc|ad}} 814 to 820. He resided six months in Badrinath and the rest of the year in Kedarnath. Hindu followers assert that he discovered the image of Badrinath in the Alaknanda River and enshrined it in a cave near the Tapt Kund hot springs.<ref name="call"/><ref name="Swami101">{{harvnb|Swami|2004|pp=100–101}}</ref> A traditional story asserts that Shankara expelled all the Buddhists in the region with the help of the [[Parmar]] ruler king [[Kanak Pal]]. The hereditary successors of the king governed the temple and endowed villages to meet its expenses. The income from a set of villages on the route to the temple was used to feed and accommodate pilgrims. The Parmar rulers held the title "Bolanda Badrinath", meaning speaking Badrinath. They had other titles, including Shri 108 Basdrishcharyaparayan Garharaj Mahimahendra, Dharmabibhab, and Dharamarakshak Sigamani.<ref name="Guha"/>
The throne of Badrinath was named after the presiding deity; the king enjoyed ritual obeisance by the devotees before proceeding to the shrine. The practice was continued until the late 19th century.<ref name="Guha">{{harvnb|Guha|2000|p=64}}</ref> During the 16th century, the King of [[Garhwal Kingdom|Garhwal]] moved the murti to the present temple.<ref name=call/> When the state of Garhwal was divided, the Badrinath temple came under British rule but the king of Garhwal continued as the chairman of the management committee.The selection of priest is done after consultation between Garhwal and Travancore royal families<ref name="Guha"/>
The temple has undergone several major renovations due to its age and damage by an avalanche. In the 17th century, the temple was expanded by the Kings of Garhwal. After significant damage in the great 1803 Himalayan earthquake, it was largely rebuilt by the King of [[Jaipur State|Jaipur]].<ref name=dhaams/> It was still under renovation as late as the 1870s{{sfn| Baynes|1878}} but these were completed by the time of the [[First World War]].{{sfn|Chisholm|1911}} At that time, [[Badrinath|the town]] was still small, consisting of only the 20-odd huts housing the temple's staff, but the number of pilgrims was usually between seven and ten thousand.{{sfn|Chisholm|1911}} The Kumbh Meld festival held every twelve years raised the number of visitors to 50,000.{{sfn|Chisholm|1911}} The temple also enjoyed revenue from the rents owed to it by various villages bequeathed by various rajas.{{sfn| Baynes|1878}}
During 2006, the state government announced the area around Badrinath as a no construction zone to curb illegal encroachment.<ref>{{cite news|title=Uttaranchal declares Badrinath as no construction zone|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1034737141.html|newspaper=Hindustan Times|location=Badrinath|date=9 May 2006|accessdate=1 January 2014}}{{Subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref>
==Legend== [[File:Nara narayana.jpg|thumb|[[Nara-Narayana|Nara and Narayana]]]]
According to Hindu legend, god [[Vishnu]] sat in meditation at this place. During his meditation, Vishnu was unaware of cold weather. [[Lakshmi]], his consort, protected him in the form of the Badri tree ([[jujube]] or Indian date). Pleased by the devotion of Lakshmi, Vishnu named the place Badrika Ashram. According to Atkinson (1979), the place used to be a jujube forest, which is not found there today. Vishnu in the form of Badrinath is depicted in the temple sitting in the ''[[Lotus position|padmasana]]'' posture. According to the legend, Vishnu was chastised by sage [[Narada]], who saw Vishnu's consort, Lakshmi, massaging his feet. Vishnu went to Badrinath to perform austerity, meditating for a long time in padmasana. <ref name=dhaams/><ref name="Swami101"/>
The ''[[Vishnu Purana]]'' narrates another version of the origins of Badrinath. According to the tradition, [[Dharma|Dharam]] had two sons, Nar, and Narayan{{mdash}}both of which are modern names of Himalayan mountains. They chose the place to spread their religion and each of them wed the spacious valleys in the Himalayas. Searching for an ideal place to set up a hermitage, they came across the other four Badris of the Pancha Badri, namely Bridha Badri, Yog Bhadri, Dhyan Badri and Bhavish Badri. They finally found the hot and cold spring behind the Alaknanda River and named it Badri Vishal.<ref name="Swami101"/>
==Literary mention== The temple finds mention in several ancient books like ''[[Bhagavata Purana]]'', ''[[Skanda Purana]]'' and ''[[Mahabharata]]''.<ref name=Bhalla190>{{harvnb|Bhalla|2006|p=190}}</ref> According to the ''[[Bhagavata Purana]]'', "[t]here in Badrikashram the Personality of Godhead (Vishnu), in his incarnation as the sages Nar and Narayana, had been undergoing great penance since time immemorial for the welfare of all living entities".<ref name=bhagavatam>[[#Bhagavata|Bhagavata Purana]] 3.4.22</ref> The ''Skanda Purana'' states that "[t]here are several sacred shrines in heaven, on earth, and in hell; but there is no shrine like Badrinath". The area around Badrinath is also celebrated in ''[[Padma Purana]]'' as abounding in spiritual treasures.<ref name=call/> The ''Mahabharata'' revered the holy place as the one which can give salvation to devotees arriving close to if, while in other holy places they must perform religious ceremonies.<ref name=Bhalla190/> The temple is revered in ''[[Nalayira Divya Prabandham]]'', in 11 hymns in the 7th–9th century Vaishnava canon by [[Periazhwar]] and in 13 hymns in [[Thirumangai Alvar|Thirumangai Azhwar]]. It is one of the 108 ''[[Divyadesam]]'' dedicated to Vishnu, who is worshipped as Badrinath.<ref name="dinamalar">{{cite web|title=Sri Badrinath Perumal temple|url=http://temple.dinamalar.com/New.php?id=1783|publisher=Dinamalar|accessdate=1 January 2014}}</ref>
==Pilgrimage== {{Historical populations |title=Number of tourists |state=collapsed |align = left |percentages=off |1990|362757 |1995|275900 |2000|735200 |2005|566524 |2010|921950 |2012|1060000 |footnote=Sources: * <ref>{{cite web|title=Number of pilgrims the temple |url=http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=9 |publisher=Shri Badrinath - Shri Kedarnath Temples Committee |year=2006 |accessdate=1 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029195018/http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=9 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> }} {{Char Dham}}
Devotees of all faiths and all schools of thought of Hinduism visit the Badrinath Temple.<ref>[[#Rao|Rao 2008]], p. 474</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Eck|2012|pp=343–344}}</ref> All the major monastic institutions like [[Kashi Math]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Kashi Math at Badrinath|url=http://www.kashimath.org/branches/|publisher=Shree Kashi Math Samasthanam|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref> Jeeyar Mutt (Andhra mutt),<ref>{{cite web|title=Badari Ashtakshari Kshethriya Annadana Sakha Sangham, (BAKASS)|url=http://www.chinnajeeyar.org/main/content/badari-ashtakshari-kshethriya-annadana-sakha-sangham-bakass/|publisher=Chinna Jeeyar Mutt|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref> [[Udipi krishna math|Udupi Pejavar]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Udupi Mutt at Badrinath|url=http://www.vishveshavani.com/contact/|publisher=Pejavara Adhokshaja Matha, Udupi|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref> and Manthralayam Sri Raghavendra Swamy Mutts<ref>{{cite web|title=Raghavendra Mutt Branches|url=http://www.raghavendramutt.org/node/38|publisher=Raghavendra Mutt|accessdate=10 September 2014}}</ref> have their branches and guest houses there.
The Badrinath temple is one of five related shrines called [[Sapta Badri|Panch Badri]], which are dedicated to the worship of Vishnu.<ref name=bansal>{{harvnb|Bansal|2005|p=35}}</ref> The five temples are Vishal Badri - Badrinath Temple in Badrinath, [[Sapta Badri#Yogadhyan Badri|Yogadhyan Badri]] located at Pandukeshwar, Bhavishya Badri located {{convert|17|km|mi|abbr=on|1}} from Jyotirmath at Subain, Vridh Badri located {{convert|7|km|mi|abbr=on|1}} from Jyotirmath in Animath and Adi Badri located {{convert|17|km|mi|abbr=on|1}} from [[Karnaprayag]]. The temple is considered one of the holiest Hindu ''[[Char Dham]]'' (four divine) sites, comprising Rameswaram, Badrinath, [[Puri]] and [[Dwarka]].<ref name="Chakra">{{harvnb|Chakravarti|1994|p=140}}</ref> Although the temple's origins are not clearly known, the [[Advaita]] school of Hinduism established by Adi Shankara attributes the origin of Char Dham to the seer.<ref name="Mittal"/> The four monasteries are located across the four corners of India and their attendant temples are Badrinath Temple at Badrinath in the North, [[Jagannath Temple, Puri|Jagannath Temple]] at Puri in the East, [[Dwarkadheesh temple, Gujrat|Dwarakadheesh Temple]] at Dwarka in the West and [[Sringeri Sharada Peetham|Sri Sharada Peetam Sringeri]] at [[Sringeri]], [[Karnataka]] in the South.<ref name="Chakra"/><ref name="Mittal"/>
Though ideologically the temples are divided between the sects of Hinduism, namely [[Saivism]] and [[Vaishnavism]], the Char Dham pilgrimage is an all-Hindu affair.<ref name="Brockman">{{harvnb|Brockman|2011|pp=94–96}}</ref> There are four abodes in the Himalayas called Chota Char Dham (''Chota'' meaning small): Badrinath, [[Kedarnath]], [[Gangotri]] and [[Yamunotri]]{{mdash}}all of which lie in the foothills of the Himalayas.<ref name="Mittal">{{harvnb|Mittal |2004|pp=482–483}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Badrinath temple reopens for Hindu pilgrims|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-2340841281.html|newspaper=Hindustan Times|location=Chamoli|date=9 May 2011|accessdate=1 January 2014}}{{Subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> The name ''Chota'' was added during the mid of 20th century to differentiate the original Char Dhams. As the number of pilgrims to these places has increased in modern times, it is called Himalayan Char Dham.<ref>{{harvnb|Melton|Baumann|2010|p=540}}</ref>
The journey across the four cardinal points in India is considered sacred by Hindus, who aspire to visit these temples once in their lifetimes.<ref name="Gwynne">{{harvnb|Gwynne|2009|loc=Section on Char Dham}}</ref> Traditionally, the pilgrimage starts at the eastern end from Puri, proceeding clockwise in a manner typically followed for circumambulation in Hindu temples.<ref name="Gwynne"/>
==Festivals and religious practices== [[File:Badri Night.JPG|thumb|Badrinath Temple at Night|alt=image of the temple at night illuminated with green light]] The most prominent festival held at Badrinath Temple is Mata Murti Ka Mela, which commemorates the descent of the river [[Ganges]] on mother earth. The mother of Badrinath, who is believed to have divided the river into twelve channels for the welfare of earthly beings, is worshiped during the festival. The place where the river flowed became the holy land of Badrinath.<ref name="festivals"/>
The [[Badri Kedar]] festival is celebrated during the month of June in both the temple and the Kedarnath temple. The festival lasts for eight days; artists from all over the country perform during the function.<ref name="festivals">{{cite web|title=Festivals celebrated in the temple |url=http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=11 |publisher=Shri Badrinath - Shri Kedarnath Temples Committee |year=2006 |accessdate=1 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217172228/http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=11 |archivedate=17 February 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
The major religious activities (or ''[[puja (Hinduism)|pujas]]'') performed every morning are ''mahabhishek'' (ablution), ''[[Abhisheka|abhishek]]'', ''gitapath'' and ''bhagavat puja'', while in the evening the ''pujas'' include ''geet govinda'' and ''[[aarti]]''. Recital in vedic scripts like ''Ashtotram'' and ''[[Sahasranama]]'' is practiced during all the rituals. After ''aarti'', the decorations are removed from the image of Badrinath and sandalwood paste is applied to it. The paste from the image is given to the devotees the next day as [[prasad]] during the ''nirmalaya [[Darśana|darshan]]''. All the rituals are performed in front of the devotees, unlike those in some Hindu temples, where some practices are hidden from them.<ref name="Nair67"/> Sugar balls and dry leaves are the common [[prasad]] provided to the devotees. From May 2006, the practise of offering Panchamrit Prasad, prepared locally and packed in local bamboo baskets, was started.<ref>{{cite news|title=Uttaranchal declares Badrinath as no construction zone|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1034191151.html|newspaper=Hindustan Times|location=New Delhi|date=8 May 2006|accessdate=1 January 2014}}{{Subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref>
The temple is closed for winter on the auspicious day of [[bhatridwityia or later]] during October–November.<ref name="close"/> On the day of closure, ''Akhanda Jyothi'', a lamp is lit filled with [[ghee]] to last for six months.<ref name=Bhalla258/> Special ''pujas'' are performed on the day by the chief priest in the presence of pilgrims and officials of the temple.<ref>{{cite news|title=Badrinath shrine closes marking end of Chardham Yatra|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/uttarakhand/badrinath-shrine-closes-marking-end-of-chardham-yatra_742346.html|location=Dehradun|publisher=Zeenews|date=17 November 2011|accessdate=28 April 2014}}</ref> The image of Badrinath is notionally transferred during the period to the Narasimha temple at [[Jyotirmath]], located {{convert|40|mi|km|abbr=on}} away from the temple.<ref name="Lochtefeld"/> The temple is reopened around April-May on [[Akshaya tritiya]], another auspicious day on the [[Hindu calendar]].<ref name="close">{{cite news|title=Badrinath shrine closed for winter|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Badrinath-shrine-closed-for-winter/articleshow/3724410.cms|work=TNN|publisher=The Times of India|location=Dehradun|date=18 November 2008|accessdate=28 April 2014}}</ref> Pilgrims gather on the first day of opening of the temple after the winter to witness the ''Akhanda Jyothi''.<ref name=Bhalla258>{{harvnb|Bhalla|2006|p=258}}</ref>
The temple is one of the holy places where the Hindus offer oblations to ancestors with the help of the priests.<ref name="Swmami102"/> Devotees visit the temple to worship in front of the image of Badrinath in the sanctum and have a holy dip in Alaknanda River. The general belief is that a dip in the tank purifies the soul.<ref>{{harvnb|Davidson|Gitlitz|2002|p=48}}</ref>
==Administration and visit== [[File:alaknanda.jpg|left|thumb|200px|[[Alaknanda River]] in Badrinath|alt=image of Alaknanda river with a hanging bridge across it]] The Badrinath Temple was included in the Uttar Pradesh state government Act No. 30/1948 as Act no. 16,1939, which was later known as Shri Badarinath and Shri Kedarnath Mandir Act. A committee nominated by the state government administers both the temples. The act was modified in 2002 to appoint additional committee members, including Government officials and a Vice chairman.<ref>{{cite web|title=Administration of the temple |url=http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=2 |publisher=Shri Badrinath - Shri Kedarnath Temples Committee |year=2006 |accessdate=1 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029193204/http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=2 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> There are seventeen members in the board; three selected by the Uttaranchal Legislative Assembly, one member each by the [[District Councils of India|Zilla Parishad]]s of [[Pauri Garhwal district|Garhwal]]<nowiki/>, [[Tehri District|Tehri]], [[Chamoli district|Chamoli]] and [[Uttarkashi district|Uttarkashi]], and ten members nominated by the state government.<ref>{{cite web|title=Committee members of the temple |url=http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=3 |publisher=Shri Badrinath - Shri Kedarnath Temples Committee |year=2006 |accessdate=1 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029184513/http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=3 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref>
As indicated in the temple records, the priests of the temple were Shiva ascetics called Dandi Sanyasis, who belonged to [[Nambudiri]] community, a religious group common in modern [[Kerala]]. When the last of the ascetics died without an heir in 1776 AD, the king invited non-ascetic Nambudiris from Kerala for the priesthood, a practice that continues in modern times.<ref name="Lochtefeld">{{harvnb|Lochtefeld|2002|p=78}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Religious setup of the temple |url=http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=4 |publisher=Shri Badrinath - Shri Kedarnath Temples Committee |year=2006 |accessdate=1 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029192556/http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=4 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> Till 1939, all the offerings made by the devotees to the temple went to the Rawal (chief priest), but after 1939, his jurisdiction was restricted to religious affairs.<ref name="Lochtefeld"/> The administrative structure of the temple consists of a chief executive officer who executes the orders from the state government, a deputy chief executive officer, two OSDs, an executive officer, an account officer, a temple officer, and a public officer to assist the chief executive officer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Power structure of the temple |url=http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=6 |publisher=Shri Badrinath - Shri Kedarnath Temples Committee |year=2006 |accessdate=1 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029184226/http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=6 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[File:Badrinath Temple - OCT 2014.jpg|thumb|200px|View of the temple during Summer|alt=image showing Badrinath temple with the mountain in the background]] Although Badrinath is located in North India, the head priest, or Rawal, is traditionally a [[Nambudiri|Nambudiri Brahmin]] chosen from the South Indian state of [[Kerala]]. This tradition is believed to have been initiated by Adi Shankara, who was a South Indian philosopher. The Rawal (chief priest) is requested by the [[Government of Uttarakhand]] ([[Uttar Pradesh]] government before the formation of Uttarakhand state) to the [[Kerala Government]]. The candidate should possess a degree of [[Acharya]] in [[Sanskrit]], be a bachelor, well-versed in reciting ''[[mantras]]'' (sacred texts) and be from the Vaishnava sect of Hinduism. The erstwhile ruler of Garhwal, who is the tutelary head of Badrinath, approves the candidate sent by the Government of Kerala. A Tilak Ceremony is held to instate the Rawal and he is deputed from April to November when the temple remains open. The Rawal is accorded high holiness status by [[The Garhwal Rifles|Garhwal Rifles]] and the state governments of Uttarakhand and Uttar Pradesh. He is also held in high esteem by the Royals of [[Nepal]]. From April to November, he performs his duties as a temple priest. Thereafter, he either stays in Joshimutt or returns to his native village in Kerala. The duties of the Rawal starts at 4 a.m. every day with the ''[[Abhisheka]]''. He should not cross the river until Vamana Dwadasi and must adhere to ''[[Brahmacharya]]''. The Rawal is assisted by the [[Garhwali people|Garhwali]] Dimri Pundits belonging to the Village Dimmer, Nayab Rawals, Dharmadikari, Vedapathi, a group of priests, Pandas Samadhi, Bhandari, Rasoiyas (cook), devotional singer, clerk of devashram, Jal Bhariya (water keeper) and temple guards. Badrinath is one of the few temples in North India that follow the ancient Tantra-Vidhi of [[Shrauta]] tradition more common in the south.<ref name="Swmami102">{{harvnb|Swami|2004|p=102}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Outlook Traveller |url=http://traveller.outlookindia.com/fulltravelogue.aspx?id=216 |title=Badrinath |publisher=Traveller.outlookindia.com |date= |accessdate=1 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029201558/http://traveller.outlookindia.com/fulltravelogue.aspx?id=216 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hinduonnet.com/thehindu/fr/2008/07/18/stories/2008071851520400.htm|work=[[The Hindu]]|title=Badrinath Temple|date=18 July 2005|accessdate=1 January 2014}}</ref>
In 2012, the temple administration introduced a token system for visitors to the temple. Tokens indicating the time of visit were provided from three stalls in the taxi stands. Each devotee to visit the presiding deity is allocated 10–20 seconds. Proof of identity is mandatory to enter the temple.<ref>{{cite web|title=News about the temple |url=http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=29 |publisher=Shri Badrinath - Shri Kedarnath Temples Committee |year=2006 |accessdate=1 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029195444/http://www.badarikedar.org/content-badari.aspx?id=29 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> The temple is reached from [[Rishikesh]], located {{convert|298|km|mi|abbr=on}} away via [[Dev Prayag]], [[Rudra Prayag]], [[Karna Prayag]], [[Nandaprayag|Nanda Prayag]], [[Joshimath]], [[Vishnuprayag]] and [[Devadarshini]]. From [[Kedarnath Temple|Kedarnath]], visitors can follow the {{convert|243|km|mi|abbr=on|adj=on}}-long Rudra Prayag route or the {{convert|230|km|mi|abbr=on|adj=on}}-long [[Ukhimath]] and [[Gopeshwar]] route.<ref name="Nair67"/>

{{Bahá'í sidebar}} The '''Bahá'í Faith in Uruguay''' began after [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], then head of the religion, mentioned the country in 1916.{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-6.html | pages = 31–32 |origyear = 1916-17}} The first Bahá'í to enter the country was [[Martha Root]] in 1919.{{cite web | last = Allmar | first = Husayn | title = Martha Root’s Journey to Chile | work = The Chilean Temple Initiative | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of the United State | year = 2007 | url = http://www.chilean-temple.org/content/view/27/45/ | accessdate = 2008-03-05| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080323081114/http://www.chilean-temple.org/content/view/27/45/| archivedate= 23 March 2008 | deadurl= no}} The first [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneer]] to settle there was Wilfrid Barton early in 1940 and the first Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] of [[Montevideo]] was elected in 1942.{{cite book | last = Lamb | first = Artemus | title = The Beginnings of the Bahá'í Faith in Latin America:Some Remembrances, English Revised and Amplified Edition | publisher = M L VanOrman Enterprises |date=November 1995 | location = 1405 Killarney Drive, West Linn OR, 97068, United States of America | url =http://bahai-library.com/lamb_bahai_latin_america}} By 1961 Uruguayan Bahá'ís had elected the first [[National Spiritual Assembly]] and by 1963 there were three Local Assemblies plus other communities.[http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1#22 The Bahá'í Faith: 1844-1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953-1963], Compiled by [[Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land, pages 22, 46, 127 By 2001 there was an estimated 4,000 Bahá'ís in Uruguay.{{cite web| author = U.S. State Department | title = Uruguay - International Religious Freedom Report 2001 | publisher = The Office of Electronic Information, Bureau of Public Affair | year = 2001 | url =https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2001/5721.htm | accessdate = 2009-07-03| archiveurl= http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20090807084710/http%3A//www%2Estate%2Egov/g/drl/rls/irf/2001/5721%2Ehtm| archivedate= August 7, 2009 | deadurl= no}} ==`Abdu'l-Bahá's Tablets of the Divine Plan== [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]], the son of the founder of the religion, wrote a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the United States in 1916-1917; these letters were compiled together in the book titled [[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]. The sixth of the tablets was the first to mention Latin American regions and was written on April 8, 1916, but was delayed in being presented in the United States until 1919 — after the end of World War I and the [[Spanish flu]]. The first actions on the part of Bahá'í community towards Latin America were that of a few individuals who made trips to Mexico and South America near or before this unavailing in 1919, including Mr. and Mrs. Frankland, and [[Hands of the Cause#Appointed posthumously by Shoghi Effendi|Roy C. Wilhelm]], and [[Martha Root]]. Root's travels, perhaps the first Bahá'í to Uruguay, began in the summer of 1919 - stopping first in Brazil, then Argentina and Uruguay before setting out to cross the Andes mountains into Chile in winter. The sixth tablet was translated and presented by [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]] on April 4, 1919, and published in [[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]] magazine on December 12, 1919.{{cite book| last = Abbas | first = 'Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab (trans. and comments) | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 | url =http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}}
"His Holiness [[Christ]] says: Travel ye to the East and to the West of the world and summon the people to the [[Kingdom of God]]. … Attach great importance to the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|indigenous]] population of America ... the republics of the continent of South America—[[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]], [[Peru]], [[Brazil]], the [[The Guianas|Guiana]]s, [[Bolivia]], [[Chile]], [[Argentina]], [[Uruguay]], [[Paraguay]], [[Venezuela]]; also the islands to the north, east and west of South America, such as [[Falkland Islands]], the [[Galápagos Islands|Galapagòs]], [[Juan Fernández Islands|Juan Fernandez]], [[Trinidad and Tobago|Tobago and Trinidad]]...."
Following the release of these tablets and then `Abdu'l-Bahá's death in 1921, a few Bahá'ís began moving to or at least visiting Latin America. ===Seven Year Plan and succeeding decades=== Shoghi Effendi, head of the religion after the death of `Abdu'l-Bahá, wrote a [[Telegraphy|cable]] on May 1, 1936 to the [[Bahá'í administration#National|Bahá'í Annual Convention]] of the United States and Canada, and asked for the systematic implementation of `Abdu'l-Bahá's vision to begin. In his cable he wrote:
Appeal to assembled delegates ponder historic appeal voiced by `Abdu'l-Bahá in ''Tablets of the Divine Plan''. Urge earnest deliberation with incoming National Assembly to insure its complete fulfillment. First century of Bahá'í Era drawing to a close. Humanity entering outer fringes most perilous stage its existence. Opportunities of present hour unimaginably precious. Would to God every State within American Republic and every Republic in American continent might ere termination of this glorious century embrace the light of the Faith of Bahá'u'lláh and establish structural basis of His World Order.{{cite book |first = Shoghi |last = Effendi |authorlink = Shoghi Effendi |year = 1947 |title = Messages to America |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Committee |location = Wilmette, Illinois, USA |oclc = 5806374 |url =http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MA/ma-16.html.iso8859-1?query=Appeal | page = 6 }}
Following the May 1 cable, another cable from Shoghi Effendi came on May 19 calling for permanent [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] to be established in all the countries of Latin America. The Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of the United States and Canada appointed the Inter-America Committee to take charge of the preparations. During the 1937 Bahá'í North American Convention, Shoghi Effendi cabled advising the convention to prolong their deliberations to permit the delegates and the National Assembly to consult on a plan that would enable Bahá'ís to go to Latin America as well as to include the completion of the outer structure of the [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] in Wilmette, Illinois. In 1937 the ''First Seven Year Plan'' (1937–44), which was an international plan designed by Shoghi Effendi, gave the American Bahá'ís the goal of establishing the Bahá'í Faith in every country in Latin America. With the spread of American Bahá'ís in Latin American, Bahá'í communities and [[Local Spiritual Assemblies]] began to form in 1938 across the rest of Latin America. Early in 1940 the first pioneer, Wilfrid Barton, arrived in Uruguay. [[May Maxwell]] stopped one day in Uruguay on a trip in February 1940 and died a few days later while in [[Buenos Aires]] where Wilfrid Barton joined by newly arrived Simon Rosenzweig from Montevideo assisted in the funeral.{{cite book | last = Holley | first = Marion | title = A Compendium of Volumes of the Baha'i World I-XII, 1925-1954 | publisher = George Ronald | year = 1981 | location = Oxford | pages = 516–28 | url = http://bahai-library.com/may_ellis_maxwell_bw | doi = | id= 0853985}} Barton reports the first converts in spring of 1941 - Emilia A. Martinez Morente and Abraham Kassabian in Montevideo.{{cite journal | title = Inter-American News; Uruguay | journal = Bahá'í News |date=May 1941 | issue = 143 | page = 8 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} The first Local Assembly of [[Montevideo]] was elected in 1942. Later in 1942 Barton reports of 13 Bahá'ís and work was progressing in translating some literature including [[The Dawn-Breakers]].{{cite journal | title = Inter-American News; Uruguay | journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1942 | issue = 155 | page = 7 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} ==After World War II== In the midst of World War II there is a report that the assembly of Montevideo was dissolved in early 1945{{cite journal | title = Inter-American News | journal = Bahá'í News |date=June 1945 | issue = 145 | page = 7 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} but was re-established by summer 1945.{{cite journal | title = Inter-American News; Uruguay | journal = Bahá'í News |date=June 1945 | issue = 175 | page = 10 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} Barton was joined by pioneer Flora Hottes in early 1946.{{cite journal | title = Inter-American News; News from Pioneers | journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1946 | issue = 181 | page = 4 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} A regional committee to coordinate efforts and build unity and familiarity in regions leading to regional national assemblies were appointed in 1946 - Chili, Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay were in one such committee's jurisdiction.{{cite journal | title = Inter-American News; Regional Committees | journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1946 | issue = 186 | page = 5 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} Retrospectively, a stated purpose for the regional committee was to facilitate a shift in the balance of roles from North American guidance and Latin cooperation to Latin guidance and North American cooperation.{{cite journal | title = Historical Background of the Panama Temple| journal = Bahá'í News |date=April 1972 | issue = 493 | page = 2 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} The process was well underway by 1950 and was to be enforced about 1953. The second South American Bahá'í Congress was celebrated in Santiago, Chile, in January, 1948 with Uruguayan delegate Gambeta Roldan. When the regional national assembly of South America was elected the members included Rangvald Taetz of Uruguay. By 1950 there was still the one assembly in Uruguay. In 1956 the Bahá'ís of Montevideo hosted the sixth convention to elect the regional assembly of South America.{{cite journal | title = Dedication of Haziratu'l-Quds at Montevideo Precedes Sixth South American Convention| journal = Bahá'í News |date=July 1956 | issue = 305 | page = 5 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} The regional assembly was reorganized in 1957 to be made up of Chile, Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay & Bolivia; one member was Roberto Cazcarra of Montevideo.{{cite journal | title = Public Meeting at the National School Of Drama… | journal = Bahá'í News |date=December 1957 | issue = 322 | page = 10 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In early 1958 the Bahá'ís of Montevideo held their first summer school{{cite journal | title = Spirit of Rededication Emerges From South American Schools; Special School for Huanuni Indian Pioneers | journal = Bahá'í News |date=May 1958 | issue = 328 | page = 21 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} and in the fall of 1959 eighteen Bahá'ís gathered for a conference to discuss the progress of the religion in Uruguay.{{cite journal | title = Four South American Countries Hold Teaching Conferences During Year | journal = Bahá'í News |date=May 1958 | issue = 348 | page = 13 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In December 1959 the Montevideo newspaper [[El País (Uruguay)|El País]] covered a presentation on Israel, which mentioned the Bahá'í Faith.{{cite journal | title = Baha'i in the News | journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1960 | issue = 353 | page = 14 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In spring 1960 Hand of the Cause [[William Sears (Bahá'í)|William Sears]] visited the Bahá'ís in Minas.{{cite journal | title = Spirit of Rededication Emerges From South American Schools; Special School for Huanuni Indian Pioneers | journal = Bahá'í News |date=June 1960 | issue = 351 | page = 15 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In late 1960 the secretary of the regional assembly, Chilean Salvador Tormo, died in a plane crash in Uruguay.{{cite journal | title = Salvador Tormo, Indefatigable Servant of Faith, Dies in Airplane Crash in Uruguay | journal = Bahá'í News |date=November 1960 | issue = 356 | page = 3 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In 1961 each country of the regional assembly elected its own National Spiritual Assembly - Uruguay's was witnessed by [[Hand of the Cause]], [[`Alí-Akbar Furútan]].{{cite web | last = Harper | first = Barron | title = Biography | work = The Furutan Academy | publisher = The Furutan Academy | year = 2007 | url = http://www.furutanacademy.org/mod/resource/view.php?id=24 | doi = | accessdate = 2009-07-03}} The members of the first Uruguayan national assembly were: Leopolda Caraballo, Else Cazcarra, Roberto Cazcarra, Mary Dutra, Francisco Flores, Elena Caraballo, Mario Regina Marius, Carola Escofet, and Edward Belcher.{{cite journal | title = Six More Latin-American NSAs Report on Formation; Uruguay | journal = Bahá'í News |date=August 1961 | issue = 365 | page = 6| url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} By 1963 there were Local Spiritual Assemblies also in [[Maldonado, Uruguay|Maldonado]], and [[Minas, Uruguay|Minas]], and a smaller group in [[Juan Lacaze]] (see [[List of cities in Uruguay]].) ==Modern community== The contributions of the community were noted in 1995 when three Uruguayan senators urged a favorable vote supporting the human rights of Iran's Bahá'ís, saying: "A vote in this sense will not only be in accordance with the country's tradition, but shall encourage the members of this community to continue their benevolent work within Uruguay and the rest of the world."{{Cite journal | author = Universal House of Justice | title = 1995-96 Update: The Situation of the Bahá'ís in Iran | journal = The Bahá'í World | publisher = Bahá'í World Centre | pages = 139–144 | year = 1997 | url = http://info.bahai.org/article-1-8-3-9.html | isbn =}} There have been some well known Baha'is who have lived in Uruguay. In 1968 [[Alfredo Speranza]], an Uruguayan pianist who's given concerts in Uruguay and other countries, became a member of the religion.{{cite journal | title = Music Lends Prestige to the Faith| journal = Bahá'í News |date=February 1972 | issue = 491 | page = 20 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}}[http://www.augustorobiati.it/speranza.htm Augusto Robiati on Alfredo Speranza] In 2004, Uruguayan artist Sima Baher was invited to exhibit her art by the embassy of Uruguay in Argentina at the Borges Cultural Center.{{cite news | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | title = Paintings of peace and unity on display | work = Bahá'í World News Service | place = Buenos Aires, Argentina | pages = | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | date = 2004-02-29 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/298 | accessdate = 2009-07-03}} In 1984, [[Phil Sisson]] left New York City and traveled to South America where he served as a Bahá'í pioneer. His first recording, "The Dream" was recorded in Montevideo and featured Baha'i chants of the Hidden Words by Baha'u'llah, prayers and meditations, and original songs. Sisson also toured throughout the region with [[Raul Medina]], and hosted his own television show called "Oro Solido" on Uruguayan national TV and throughout [[Río de la Plata]], was guest performer on ''Telecataplum'' (see [[Canal 12 (Argentina)|Canal 12]]), and performed at [[La Allianaza]], was a featured guest artist in the "Miss Hawaiian Tropic Beauty Pageant in Punta del Este", and was invited to perform at the Israeli Embassy in Montevideo. Sisson married Lena Hedayatzadeh in 1989, two years after adopting Lua Aline who (in 2004) served for three months at the [[Baha'i Lotus Temple]] in New Delhi, India. - "Her service was the sweetest affirmation and compliment she could have ever bestowed upon us." In 2006, Sisson released his second recording, "We're One People" in San Diego, California.{{cite web | last = Sisson | first = Phil | title = We'reOnePeople | work = Bitmunk Collection | publisher = Digital Bazaar, Inc. | year = 2006 | url =http://bitmunk.com/media/6537401 | doi = | accessdate = 2009-07-03}} There have also been activities noted among the community in general. Bahá'ís from Uruguay pioneered to the Falkland Islands{{cite journal | title = First Baha'i Conference in the Folklands| journal = Bahá'í News |date=June 1973 | issue = 507 | page = 24 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} and Brazil.{{cite journal | title = Brazil; Amazon a 'new frontier' for pioneers| journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1985 | issue = 648 | pages = 6–8 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} Summer schools held in Uruguay showed 87 attendees in 1985{{cite journal | title = The World; Uruguay| journal = Bahá'í News |date=July 1985 | issue = 652 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 16 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} and 93 in 1987,{{cite journal | title = Around the World; Uruguay| journal = Bahá'í News |date=June 1986 | issue = 663 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 14 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} when Bahá'ís were believed to live in 96 locations in Uruguay.{{cite journal | title = Uruguay| journal = Bahá'í News |date=March 1988 | issue = 684 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 3 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} By 1988 a community of Bahá'ís was to be found in [[Maldonado, Uruguay|Maldonado]].{{cite journal | title = The World; Uruguay| journal = Bahá'í News |date=May 1989 | issue = 697 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 15 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} In 1989 the Bahá'ís of Montevideo hosted two events; underr the auspices of the national assembly the first was an international women's conference attracting about 300 people from 12 countries.{{cite journal| title = The World; Uruguay| journal = Bahá'í News |date=January 1990 | issue = 705 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 16 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} and second, held through the work of the local assembly, was an "Evening of Cultural Integration" brought together representatives from Armenian, African, and Israeli ethnicities including cultural forms of dress and talks on integrating into Uruguayan community.{{cite journal| title = The World; 'Cultural evening' in Uruguay| journal = Bahá'í News |date=April 1990 | issue = 708 |issn=0195-9212 | page = 8 | url =http://www.teachingandprojects.com/meansandmaterials.htm}} Fifty-five members of the religion from Uruguay joined those from across Brazil and other places for a 2008 regional conference called for by the [[Universal House of Justice]] in São Paulo.{{cite news | last = Bahá'í International Community | first = | author-link = Bahá'í International Community | title = The São Paulo Regional Conference | work = Bahá'í World News Service | place = São Paulo, Brazil | pages = | publisher = Bahá’í International Community | date = 2008-12-21 | url =http://news.bahai.org/community-news/regional-conferences/saopaulo.html | accessdate = 2009-07-03}} ===Demographics=== By 2001 there was an estimated 4,000 Bahá'ís, about 0.2% of the national population according to the [[World Christian Encyclopedia|World Christian Database]],{{cite web| title =ARDA: International > Regions > South America > Uruguay | work = the arda.com | publisher = thearda.com| year = 2001| url =http://www.thearda.com/internationaldata/countries/Country_235_2.asp | doi = | accessdate = 2009-07-03}} concentrated primarily in Montevideo. The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated some 7,300 Bahá'ís in 2005.{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | doi = | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} ==See also== *[[Religion in Uruguay]] *[[History of Uruguay]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.bahai.org.uy/}} *[http://www.lacuestionbahai.org/ Official Website of the Bahá'ís of Montevideo] {{Latin America and the Caribbean topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith in Uruguay}} [[Category:Religion in Uruguay]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith by country|Uruguay]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith in South America|Uruguay]]

[[File:BIC-logo.png|right]] The '''Bahá'í International Community''', or the '''BIC''', is an international [[non-governmental organization]] (NGO) representing the members of the [[Bahá'í Faith]];<ref name="mcmullen">{{cite book | title = The Baha'i: The religious Construction of a Global Identity | year = 2000 | first = Michael | last= McMullen | publisher = Rutgers University Press | location = New Brunswick, N.J. | isbn = 0-8135-2836-4 | page = 39 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=lF0UquZAZW8C}}</ref><ref name="bic">{{cite web | title = About the Bahá’í International Community | url = http://bic.org/who-we-are/copy_of_Baha2019i-International-Community | year = 2008 | publisher = Bahá’í International Community | accessdate = 2008-02-10| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080312003514/http://bic.org/who-we-are/copy_of_Baha2019i-International-Community| archivedate= 12 March 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> it was first chartered in March 1948 with the [[United Nations]], and currently has affiliates in over 180 countries and territories.<ref name="bic"/><ref name="child">{{cite book | title = Religious Dimensions of Child and Family Life: Reflections on the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child | chapter = Child and Family in Baha'i Religion| first = John | last = Hatcher | editor = Coward, Harold G. |editorlink=Harold Coward | year = 1996 | publisher = University of Victoria | location = Victoria, B.C.| isbn = 1-55058-104-X | page = 156}}</ref>
[[Hilda Yen]] was a founding and key figure in the establishment of the BIC according to [[Mildred Mottahedeh]]. Mottahedeh underscored Yen's service upon her death in 1970: "This noble lady played an important role in the development of the Baha'i Faith in the international field, and it was through her efforts that the Baha'is began their work with the United Nations",<ref>{{cite news | title =In Memoriam | newspaper =Bahá'í News | page = 2 | date =July 1970 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=07&page=586 | accessdate = }}</ref> and wrote a memorial.<ref name="MottaMem">Baha'i World, XV, 1968-73, pp. 476-78."In Memoriam; Hilda Yank Sing Yen 1905 - 1970" by Mildred Mottahedeh.</ref>
The BIC seeks to "promote world peace by creating the conditions in which unity emerges as the natural state of human existence"<ref name="mcmullen"/> by promoting and applying principles which are derived from the teachings of the Bahá'í Faith to develop a united and sustainable civilization.<ref name="bic"/> The BIC also works on the advancement of [[human rights]], the advancement of women, universal education, the encouragement of just economic development, the protection of the environment, and a sense of [[world citizenship]].<ref name="mcmullen"/><ref name="bic"/>
To achieve its purpose, the BIC cooperates with governments, the United Nations and other inter-governmental and non-governmental organizations;<ref name="bic"/> in May 1970 it gained consultative status with the [[United Nations Economic and Social Council]] (ECOSOC) and in 1976 with the [[United Nations Children's Fund]] (UNICEF).<ref name="mcmullen"/><ref name="child"/> Then in 1989 the BIC developed a working relationship with the [[World Health Organization]], and it also has a working relationship with various other United Nations agencies and enterprises including the [[UN Development Fund for Women]] (UNIFEM) and [[United Nations Environment Programme]] (UNEP).<ref name="mcmullen"/><ref name="bic2">{{cite web|title=The Bahá’í World 2005–2006: Activities |url=http://bic.org/statements-and-reports/year-in-review/the-baha2019i-world-200520132006 |year=2006 |publisher=Bahá’í International Community |accessdate=2008-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518081815/http://bic.org/statements-and-reports/year-in-review/the-baha2019i-world-200520132006 |archivedate=2008-05-18 |df= }}</ref> The BIC has also undertaken joint development programs with various other United Nations agencies; in the 2000 [[Millennium Development Goals|Millennium Forum]] of the [[United Nations]] a Bahá'í was invited as the only non-governmental speaker during the summit.<ref>{{cite web| author= Bahá'í World News Service| publisher= Bahá'í International Community| title= Bahá'í United Nations Representative Addresses World Leaders at the Millennium Summit| url= http://www.bahai.org/article-1-1-0-3.html| date= 2000-09-08| accessdate= 2006-06-01| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060422130330/http://www.bahai.org/article-1-1-0-3.html| archivedate= 2006-04-22| deadurl= yes| df= }}</ref>
The Bahá'í International Community has offices at the [[United Nations]] in [[New York City|New York]] and [[Geneva]] and representations to United Nations regional commissions and other offices in [[Addis Ababa]], [[Bangkok]], [[Nairobi]], [[Rome]], [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]], and [[Vienna]].<ref name="bic"/> In recent years an Office of the Environment and an Office for the Advancement of Women were established as part of its United Nations Office. There also exists an Office of Public Information which is based at the [[Bahá'í World Centre]] in [[Haifa, Israel]]; that office distributes information about the Bahá'í Faith and publishes [[ONE COUNTRY]], a quarterly newsletter.<ref name="bic"/>
On 4 March 2009, the Bahá'í International Community released an open letter to Iran’s Chief Prosecutor, Ayatollah Qorban-Ali Dorri-Najafabadi, addressing his recent statements regarding the administrative affairs of the Bahá’ís of Iran.<ref name="openletter">{{cite web | title = Open letter to Iran's Chief Prosecutor | url = http://bic.org/areas-of-work/persecution/prosecutor-general-iran-en.pdf | year = 2009 | publisher = Bahá’í International Community | accessdate = 2009-03-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090407050931/http://bic.org/areas-of-work/persecution/prosecutor-general-iran-en.pdf| archivedate= 7 April 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

{{About|the book mentioned in Christian and Jewish religious teachings|other uses|The Book of Life (disambiguation){{!}}The Book of Life}}
In Christianity and Judaism, the '''Book of Life''' ([[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: ספר החיים, [[Romanization of Hebrew|transliterated]] ''Sefer HaChaim''; {{Lang-el|βιβλίον τῆς ζωῆς}} ''Biblíon tēs Zōēs'') is the [[book]] in which [[God]] records the names of every person who is destined for [[Heaven]] or the [[World to Come]].{{cn|date=May 2018}} According to the [[Talmud]] it is open on [[Rosh Hashanah]], as is its analog for the [[Evil|wicked]], the '''Book of the Dead'''. For this reason extra mention is made for the Book of Life during [[Amidah]] recitations during the [[High Holidays|Days of Awe]], the ten days between Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish [[new year]], and [[Yom Kippur]], the day of atonement (the two [[High Holidays]], particularly in the prayer [[Unetaneh Tokef]]).
==In the Hebrew Bible== In the [[Hebrew Bible]] the Book of Life—the book or [[Muster (military)|muster-roll]] of God—records forever all people considered [[righteousness|righteous]] before God.{{cn|date=May 2018}} To be blotted out of this book signifies [[death]].<ref>Shemot ([[Book of Exodus]]) [http://www.breslov.com/bible/Exodus32.htm#33 32:33]</ref> It is with reference to the Book of Life that the holy remnant is spoken of as being written unto life<ref>A. V., "among the living"</ref> in [[Jerusalem]];<ref>{{bibleref2|Isaiah|4:3}}</ref> compare also Ezekiel 9:4, where one of the six heavenly envoys "who had the scribe's [[inkhorn]] upon his loins" is told to mark the righteous for life, while the remainder of the inhabitants of Jerusalem are doomed. The [[Psalms]] also speaks of a book of the living: "Let them be blotted out of the book of the living, and not be written with the righteous.<ref>{{bibleref2|Psalms|69:28}}; compare {{bibleref2|Psalms|139:16}}.</ref>
Even the tears of men are recorded in this Book of God.<ref>{{bibleref2|Psalms|56:9}}</ref> "Every one that shall be found written in the book . . . shall awake to everlasting life".<ref>{{bibleref2|Daniel|12:1}} et seq.</ref> This book is probably identical with the "Book of Remembrance" in which are recorded the deeds of those that [[Fear of God#Judaism|fear the Lord]].<ref>{{bibleref2|Malachi|3:16}}</ref>
== In apocrypha== The [[Apocrypha|apocryphal]] [[Book of Jubilees]]<ref>xxx. 20-22.</ref> speaks of two heavenly tablets or books: a Book of Life for the righteous, and a Book of Death for those that walk in the paths of impurity and are written down on the heavenly tablets as adversaries (of God). Also, according to Jubilees 36:10, one who contrives evil against his neighbor will be blotted out of the Book of Remembrance of men, and will not be written in the Book of Life, but in the Book of Perdition. In Daniel 12:10 and Enoch 47:3 "the [[Ancient of Days]]" is described as seated upon [[Throne of God|his throne]] of glory with "the Book" or "the Books of Life" ("of the Living") opened before him. So are, according to Enoch 56:1, the righteous "written before the glory of the Great One," and, according to Enoch 108:3, the transgressors "blotted out of the ''Book of Life'' and out of the books of the holy ones." Reference is made also in [[The Shepherd of Hermas]] (Vision i. 3; Mandate viii.; Similitude ii.); in Revelation 3:5, 13:8, 17:8, 20:12–15, where "two Books" are spoken of as being "opened before the throne, the Book of Life, and the Book of Death, in which latter the unrighteous are recorded together with their evil deeds, in order to be cast into the [[lake of fire]]." It is the ''Book of Life'' in which the [[Twelve apostles|apostles']] names are "written in heaven" (Luke 10:20), or "the fellow-workers" of [[Apostle Paul|Paul]] (Phil 4:3), and "the assembly of the first-born" (Hebrews 12:23; compare I Clem. 45). Allusion is made also in Enoch 81:4, 89:61–77, 90:17–20, 98:76, 104:7; [[2 Baruch]] 24:1; [[Ascension of Isaiah]] 9:20.
==In the New Testament== The Book of Life is referred to seven times in the [[Book of Revelation]] (3:5 13:8 17:8 20:12 20:15 21:27 22:19) one of the books of the [[New Testament]], attributed to [[John of Patmos]]. As described, only those whose names are written in the Book of Life from the foundation of the world, and have not been blotted out by the [[Lamb of God|Lamb]], are saved at the [[Last Judgment]]; all others are doomed. "And whosoever was not found written in the book of life was cast into the [[lake of fire]]" (''Rev.'' 20:15, [[King James Version]]). "And I saw the dead, small and great, stand before God; and the books were opened: and another book was opened, which is the book of life: and the dead were judged out of those things which were written in the books, according to their works". (''Rev.'' 20:12, King James Version)
It is also mentioned in Pauls letter to the Philippians 4:3.
==The eschatological or annual roll-call== While the prevailing tendency among apocryphal writers of the [[Hasidean]] school was to give the Book of Life an [[eschatology|eschatological]] meaning, the Jewish liturgy and the tradition relating to the New Year and Atonement days adhered to the ancient view, which took the Book of Life in its natural meaning, preferring, from a [[pragmatism|practical]] point of view, the [[worldliness]] of Judaism to the [[mysticism|heavenliness]] of the [[Essenes]]. Instead of transferring, as is done in the [[Book of Enoch]], the [[Testament of Abraham]], and elsewhere, the great [[Judgment Day]] to the [[afterlife|hereafter]], the [[Pharisees|Pharisaic school]] taught that on the first day of each year (''Rosh Hashanah''), [[Jewish eschatology|God sits in judgment]] over his [[Animal|creatures]] and has the Books of Life together with the books containing the records of the righteous and the wicked.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
The origin of the [[heaven]]ly Book of Life must be sought in [[Babylonia]], where legends<ref>See ''Creation Tab.'' iv. 121, and the ''Zu'' legend, ii. 7, quoted in Harper's "Babylonische Legenden," in ''Beitr. z. Assyriologie'' by Delitzsch and Haupt, 1892, ii. 2, p. 412.</ref> speak of the [[Tablets of Destiny]] and of tablets containing the [[Sin|transgression]]s, [[sin]]s, [[wrongdoing]]s, [[curse]]s and [[execration]]s of a person who should be "cast into the water"; that is, blotted out.<ref>Compare ''Micah'' vii. 19 and the art. ''Tashlik''.</ref> The living are the righteous,<ref>''Ps.'' lxix.29.</ref> who alone are admitted to [[citizenship]] in the [[theocracy]], while the [[wickedness|wicked]] are denied membership and [[eternal punishment|blotted out]] of God's book (''Ex.'' xxxii. 32 ''et seq''.).<ref>''Ezek.'' xiii. 9; ''Jer.'' xxii. 30; and ''Ex.'' xxxii. 30-34, accordingly assigned by Holzinger to a late stratum; see his commentary.</ref> The life in which the righteous participate is to be understood in a temporal sense, as temporal life is apparently prayed for in the [[liturgy|liturgical formula]]: "Inscribe us in the Book of Life."{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
In ''Daniel'' xii. 1, however, those who are found written in the book and who escape the [[tribulation|troubles]] preparatory to the coming of the [[messiah|Messianic]] kingdom are they who, together with the [[Resurrection|risen]] [[martyr]]s, are destined to share in [[everlasting life]]. Eternal life is certainly meant in ''Enoch'' xlvii. 3, civ. 1, cviii. 3, and frequently in the ''[[New Testament]]'', especially in ''[[Book of Revelation|Revelation]]''. The [[Targum]] (''Isa.'' iv. 3; ''Ezek.'' xiii. 9) speaks of the "Book of Eternal Life." The [[Mishnah]] states that the deeds of every human being are recorded in a book (''Abot,'' ii. 1; see iii. 16). The ''Sefer Ḥasidim'' (xxxiii) pointedly adds that God is in no need of a book of records; "the Torah speaks the [[language]] of man."{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
== Fundraising ==
A book of life motif is frequently found in Jewish houses of worship. It is both a decorative feature and fundraiser. Some synagogues have raised money by inscribing congregation member's names in a "book of life" as a tribute to their financial generosity.
==See also== * [[Predestination]] * [[Tree of life]] * [[Water of Life (Christianity)]]
==Notes== <references/>
==References== *Charles, ''Book of Enoch'', pp. 131–133 *[[Gustaf Dalman]], ''Worte Jesu'', p. 171. *JAL, "The Book of Life."

{{Infobox political party |name = Central Jewish Bureau, Communist Party of Poland |native_name = Centralne Biuro Żydowskie |country = Poland |ideology = [[Communism]] |position = [[Far-left]] }} The '''Central Jewish Bureau''' ({{lang-pl|Centralne Biuro Żydowskie}}, CBŻ) was a [[Jewish]] autonomous section inside the [[Communist Party of Poland]]. The CBŻ was founded shortly after the [[Communist Bund (Poland)|Kombund]] had merged into the Communist Party in 1923. The role of the CBŻ was to mobilize support for the Communist Party amongst the Jewish community.<ref>Jaff Schatz. Jews and the communist movement in interwar Poland. In: Jonathan Frankel. [https://books.google.com/books?id=POkxdm6DoAsC&pg=PA13&lpg=PA13&dq=jaff+schatz+jews+communism&source=web&ots=B5QNMKyJ49&sig=KW-p4_cdwuVM_kHyU9zifzYbX8M&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result#PPA30,M1 Dark Times, Dire Decisions: Jews and Communism. Studies in Contemporary Jewry.] Oxford University Press US, 2005, p. 20.</ref> However, not all Jewish party members were part of the CBŻ; assimilated Jewish communists were active in the main Polish party organization.<ref>Joseph Marcus. [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN9027932395&id=82ncGA4GuN4C&pg=PA362&lpg=PA362&ots=wlRamGIAQ3&dq=zydokomuna+endeks&sig=oiNo2S0bQl7bW6EUb3edvKEcKXg#PPA290,M1 Social and Political History of the Jews in Poland, 1919-1939.] Walter de Gruyter, 1983. p. 290.</ref>
